Away, thou shame-fac'd modest maid!</br>Too much to thee my court I've paid,</br>But now my faults I see;</br>There's nought from thee I can expect</br>But poverty and cool neglect,</br>'Twill never do for me:

But come, bold maid!  with sprightly looks,</br>Pregnant with wit ne'er learn'd from books</br>(For books make ladies dull);</br>Be thou my friend, sweet IMPUDENCE!</br>Let learning, modesty, and sense,</br>No more possess my skull.

I like thy meretricious air,</br>That wanton eye, that bosom bare,</br>Inviting to the touch;</br>Thy well-turn'd limbs become the gauze,</br>Thy beauty strikes, but never awes,</br>Nor can we love too much.

For long by Modesty restrain'd,</br>From seeking thee I have refrain'd,</br>But now I've broke the chain;</br>Her blushing cheeks, her downcast eyes,</br>Her formal lessons I despise,</br>Preach'd up to me in vain.

For oft the man of modest mien,</br>In lowly sphere to move is seen,</br>While fools, with face of brass,</br>By Fortune favour'd high will rise,</br>Altho' the tongue of envy cries,</br>He's nothing but an ass.
And now my humble vot'ry hear,</br>Blest Impudence!  to me give ear,</br>Inspirer of my song;</br>Infuse thy spirit in each vein,</br>That backwardness which you disdain,</br>Let me not keep it long.
And teach me to assume that face,</br>Which far surpasseth ev'ry grace</br>That modesty can boast;</br>That look important, vainly big,</br>Oft seen beneath the bushy wig</br>At bar or pulpit toss'd:

And may I learn to prize my worth,</br>And set my parts and genius forth</br>In such conspicuous light,</br>That gaping fools, with curious stare,</br>May wonder how these talents were</br>Conceal'd so long in night.

Give me with stately stride to walk,</br>With empty sounding words to talk,</br>Such as the ladies hear,</br>When, tattling by their sides, the beaux</br>Now praise their tops, and now their toes,</br>With many a foolish sneer.
And far be diffidence from me;</br>That bashful maid Humility</br>I turn away with scorn;</br>The man of humble lowly views</br>Is like the vulgar grov'ling Muse,</br>To greatness never born.

Thus, Impudence!  by thee inspir'd,</br>That quality so long admir'd,</br>But never yet assum'd;</br>With pertness, boldness, on my side,</br>And all the insolence of pride,</br>For Fortune's smile I'm doom'd.
For modest merit tries in vain</br>A scrimped livelihood to gain;</br>But Impudence presides</br>At court, at church, and on the bench,</br>And nothing sooner wins a wench,</br>Or for a man provides.
Then mine be matchless Impudence,</br>And bold Assurance, void of sense,</br>To bear me up in life;</br>The little Modesty I have,</br>Now lost to me, I freely leave</br>To ev'ry modern wife.</br>
